1557832.folder: 423-429 Canal Street - Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
1557832.title: 423-429 Canal Street - Varick Street

718036f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718036f-a.text:
(1)
431 to 447 Canal Street, at, adjoining, and west of the N.W.
corner of Varick Street.
October 10, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Nearly the same view after the clearing of the block: Canal Street, site of 435 to 447, adjoining and west of the N.W.
corner of Varick Street.
February 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

718037f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718037f-a.text:
Canal Street, north side, west from and including Varick St.
(1)
Canal Street, S.W. corner and north side, west from and including Varick Street. Notice the little one-story frame structure on Varick Street, adjoining the N.W. corner. The building at the S.W. corner will have to be demolished to make room for the exit from the eastbound tube of the Holland Vehicular Tunnel.
December, 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, nearly five years later, just before the opening of the Holland Vehicular Tunnel. The exit, at the left of this
picture, is closed by a temporary board fence.
October 10, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, a restrioted view showing the demolition of the old houses in the block bounded by Canal, Varick, and Watts Streets.
February 5, 1929.
L. Sperr.

718038f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718038f-a.text:
Canal Street, west from Varick Street, showing in the foreground, left and right respectively, the low triangular Tunnel Adminstration Building, and the 16 story Holland Plaza Building. The Holland funnel exit appears adjacent to the former,
utilising the southerly side of Canal Street.
January 26, 1936
W.P.A. Photo
Five Boroughs Project

718039f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718039f-a.text:
Canal Street (cars driving eastward thereupon), at Varick Street (right center) as viewed southeastward to show the New York Telephone Building across the roofs of buildings that face on the south side of Laight Street, extending from Varick Street to West Broadway (extreme left and "El" thereupon). The small alley-way dividing these is St. Johns Lane. This view at an earlier date would be impossible as a triangular block (No. 220 .. Bromley) was cleared in the widening of Canal Street for the Hudson Tunnel traffic. Note the signs at the right, at the mouth
of the east bound tube (Manhattan exit).
View No. 2 is similar, tho it does not show Varick Street
at the right.
April 2, 1932.
View 2: July 4, 1938.
P.L. Sperr

718040f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718040f-a.text:
Canal Street, east from and including Varick Street, just before the demolition work, in connection with the Independent (municipal)
Subway and the extension of Sixth Avenue, begins.
Early 1927.

718041f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
718041f-a.text:
Canal Street, north side, site of 449-457, between Varick and Hudson Streets, after the demolition of the old buildings in the block.
February 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723457f-a.folder: Sullivan Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY
723457f-a.text:
Sullivan Street, north from and including Canal Street, the year before the demolition of buildings for the construction of the Independent (municipal) Subway line and the southward extension of Sixth Ave. The west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand Streets, inclusive, including Nos. 2 to 24 Sullivan Street, will become part of the west side of Sixth Ave. Notice the new building (since 1922) at the S.W. corner of Grand Street. The entire east side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Watts Streets, including the ten-story Powell Chocolate factory at the east corner of Canal Street,
will be razed.
Sullivan Street begins here and runs north to West 3rd Street, and, since 1904, to Washington Square. IIt is the sixth of a group of streets named for Revolutionary generals, and laid out west of and parallel
to Broadway.
1926.

723457f-b.text:
Sullivan Street, north from and including Canal Street, the year before the demolition of buildings for the construction of the Independent (municipal) Subway line and the southward extension of Sixth Ave. The west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand Streets, inclusive, including Nos. 2 to 24 Sullivan Street, will become part of the west side of Sixth Ave. Notice the new building (since 1922) at the S.W. corner of Grand Street. The entire east side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Watts Streets, including the ten-story Powell Chocolate factory at the east corner of Canal Street,
will be razed.
Sullivan Street begins here and runs north to West 3rd Street, and, since 1904, to Washington Square. IIt is the sixth of a group of streets named for Revolutionary generals, and laid out west of and parallel
to Broadway.
1926.

723736f-a.folder: Varick Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY
723736f-a.text:
71-79 Varick Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Canal Street. Demolition of the corner building and the oneestory frame
shack is in process.
February 5, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723737f-a.text:
Varick Street, west side, site of Nos. 73 to 81, north of Canal Street and opposite the western end of Grand Street.
February 12, 1929.

723743f-a.folder: Varick Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY
723743f-a.text:
(1)
VVarick Street, west side, from Canal to watte Streets, inclusive.
February 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, with the camera a little farther north, showing the Holland Plaza Building, which has replaced the houses shown in No. 11. The north side of Canal Street from Varick to Hudson Streets
is also shown.
June 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

723745f-a.folder: Varick Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY
